Mike Stone

@mike

Husband, father, nerd. Half human, half Fosstodon Admin. Tends to tell Dad Jokes.

Don't feel obligated, but if you feel like buying me a coffee, I won't say no...

:cupofcoffee: https://ko-fi.com/mikestone :cupofcoffee:

Later
Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-12 16:34

@h4ck3r9 @kev what a meaningfully sized donation is. If, in the future, we can be making donations and gain membership to FOSS projects, I think that would be amazing. It would give the community not only the opportunity to contribute, but the opportunity to have a meaningful say in the direction of some of these projects.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-12 16:32

@h4ck3r9 @kev I think that sounds great, but right now the frequency of our donations is directly contingent on how much we're getting in donations. After paying for keeping the lights on, we're building up a "buffer" of funding that will keep Fosstodon going should something to @kev or I. Right now, we've got about 4 months of buffer saved. Our goal is 6. We'd like to make donations be of meaningful size (no $2 to the Linux Foundation). We should ask the community what the consensus is on --->

Write.as @write_as 2018-08-08 23:08

#ActivityPub support is live! You can now follow *Public* Write.as blogs from Mastodon, such as our @blog

It's limited to Public blogs right now (a paid feature) so we can slowly roll this out and plug holes as needed -- once I'm confident things are stable in the next few days, it'll be available to everyone for free.

You can read a bit more about the update, and I'd love to hear any feedback / ideas / bugs here! https://discuss.write.as/t/activitypub-support/64

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-09 23:20

@richard Yea, that's why you're not seeing the cancel option. If you a replying to a message (any message) you can convert that to a DM just by changing the permissions on the toot. If you do that, you have a cancel option. If you're typing a new message from scratch, there isn't one.

I can see where a cancel option would be beneficial to have for new messages. The consistency would be nice too.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-09 23:15

@richard Are you replying to a message in both cases? If you're typing a new message, DM or not, you don't have an X out option. The only time you do (I think unless I'm missing something) is when you're replying.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-09 23:06

@richard Not sure what you mean by "no way out". Do you mean the compose window doesn't go away?

DMs also show up with a different background color compared to other toots, so they should stand out. Plus, there will be an envelope at the bottom indicating that it's a DM and not a public toot.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-09 22:18

@wdavery @puffinux I personally don't have an issue with replicating human voices. I'd love for all these assistants to be configurable to the point of the user deciding what kind of personality they have, what they sound like, what they answer to, etc. If I want an assistant named Jeremy that sounds like Morgan Freeman with a great sense of humor, I should be able to get it. If I want one that answers to Computer and sounds like Majel Barrett with no humor, I should be able to get that too.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-09 22:00

@mattmcnutt I was wondering that too, but apparently they're still getting some decent traffic. It's decreasing steadily, but still pulled 1.9 billion hits last year. Still, the speed they've been declining has been increasing, so I wouldn't be surprised if they drop out of that list soon.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-09 21:20

@kev @puffinux @popey Well, Mycroft is configurable like most assistants these days, so you can still use the old Popey voice if you'd like. I'd like to see a new Popey 2.0, but so far I haven't heard anything about that.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-09 21:01

@puffinux I thought so too, even though I've gotten used to it over time. I like the way they've kind of made it sound natural yet electronic at the same time.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-08 15:33

@lightlazer I've heard of people going both ways. I don't see a need for me to have more than one, but I can see where people with diverging interests may want to have different instances for different communities. I can also see where they may want to not worry about multiple accounts. I don't think there's a "right way".

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 23:22

@boblmartens Very true.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 23:22

@boblmartens Well, in fairness there's very little incentive for them to look outside of Google. If you've signed up for a Gmail account (which a lot of people have) most of Google's other tools just work. You've already got the account, you don't even need to sign up. Add to that the fact that Google's tools are actually pretty good at what they do, it makes for a compelling offering. Before you know it, you're centralized on Google's stuff, and Google knows everything about you.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 23:17

@boblmartens Agreed, but Google offers a lot of simple and convenient services, so it's easy for people to get absorbed into the Google ecosystem. It's a lot harder to get back out.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 23:15

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 19:51

@joseph Depends I guess. They're such versatile machines. I have one I use for a RetroPi (gaming system). I have one I'm setting up as a PiCroft. I'm planning on setting up a PiHole for on another. There's so many things these SBCs can be used for. You can even host a Pleroma instance. All of the above actually for the price of a spare SDCard.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 18:02

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 17:59

@Wingy Just a joke for the most part. Though I and a good number of people here think that Mastodon is better than Twitter.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 17:58

@Wingy Very slick.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 17:57

@joseph I'd highly recommend them. I have at least 5 of them now, not all in use right now. The one I use the most is just setup as a work station, and I have gone out of my way to keep things light. I use i3wm. I use Alpine for mail. I use vim for text editing, Rainbowstream for Twitter, tootstream for Mastodon. Almost nothing GUI based. I rarely if ever do anything web related on that system. It lets me operate a pretty responsive system for almost no money at all. And it's not even a B+.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 04:32

@Wraptile I don't know that one way is right and the other is wrong. Stallman says FLOSS and the FSF recommends FLOSS, but I've always felt that including Libre in the acronym was kind of redundant. I can see why they did it. No one wants to call it "LOSS", and by going with #Fosstodon instead of of "Flosstodon", we're not confused for an instance for dental hygienists.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-07 02:55

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-06 23:12

@puffinux @lightlazer I actually hide the Fed. There's a lot of stuff in there that I want nothing to do with, even with filters. I love the local timeline here on Fosstodon, and I have the people I follow in my home feed that includes people outside of our instance. I have a test list that I created when I was figuring out how to use them, but for the most part I haven't found it necessary my Home and Local feeds being so good.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-06 22:45

@lightlazer To me, the Federated Timeline isn't particularly useful without the use of filters. The Local Timeline is much better, and worth looking into. It's possible with an increasingly large instance that the Local may become to noisy without filters as well, but we're around 550 users and I don't think we're near that yet. Add to that the ability to create columns based on specific lists of users from any instance, and there are a lot of ways to keep yourself from being overwhelmed.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-06 21:50

@cigarBGuitarEfx I absolutely wouldn't give up Tusky, but it looks like it would be an interesting option on my Pi workstation with w3m. I could run a much lighter browser and still be able to access Fosstodon without going to another computer or my phone.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-06 21:34

Kev Quirk @kev 2018-08-04 09:36

A couple of people from various instances have mentioned that #Mastodon is confusing at first. So I decided to write a comprehensive guide on how to get started with Mastodon.

Hopefully this helps new users to Mastodon. Please do Boost if you feel it could be useful to others.

https://kevq.uk/how-does-mastodon-work/

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-04 18:09

@ovbys8 Welcome aboard!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-04 18:09

@wdavery I still have a random collection of unknown stuff in Chrome at work, but at home I switched to Vivaldi, and I never bothered with the bookmarks at all. If there's anything in there, it's generic browser defaults.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-04 06:13

@kev @wdavery Yep. I don't even use bookmarks. I have some, but I never look. Who knows what antiquated and weird stuff is hiding in there? I might get lost and never find my way out!

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 17:32

@fatboy Yes, yes it does.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 17:32

@wdavery That's been my experience. Either have an in where you're applying, or be willing to take a job where you can build a reputation and work your way up. Internal applicants are often given a little bit more attention even if their on paper credentials are less impressive. If you're already in and you've got the know how to work your way up, that could work for you too.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 17:21

@wdavery I majored in CS many many years ago, and in my opinion the degree itself is mostly important during the job search portion. It's most helpful in getting your resume onto the desk of the person doing the hiring, and during the interview process. After you've got the job and you're doing the day to day work, just being knowledgeable of your subject matter is more important.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 03:40

Bird site link to video of tonight's dust storm. Fun right?

https://twitter.com/abc15/status/1025205946451017730

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 03:34

@kelbot That's definitely true, though I've had good luck with crowd funded stuff.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 02:33

@kelbot The C2 should fit in this enclosure too. Really, it's going to come down to enclosure features and the larger 10" screen, and whether it's worth the extra money for those things.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 01:28

@coffee Not really. Studies show that the "dust" has increased levels of hazardous materials such as fungi, pollen, heavy metals, bacteria, stockyard fecal matter, fertilizer, herbicides and pesticides. There's also a more than casual correlation between an increasing number of dust storms and an over 800% increase in cases of Valley Fever (a fungal lung infection). All told, pretty crappy.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-03 01:15

Well crap.

For those of you not familiar, that "cloud" that's a different color right above the roofline is an incoming dust storm.

@scollonp I probably could, but we went with a proprietary service to host our FTP accounts, so I'd have to go through their API. That being said, we keep NOT dumping it, and the longer we don't dump it the stupider I feel about the whole thing.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-08-02 16:16

My company just started using a Proofpoint Protection server, and I have to say it's been working pretty well. I don't know a lot about it, but I do know I get a daily digest of all the emails it's filtering out, and there's only been a single false positive. I whitelisted that address, and it's been flawless ever since. I check my digest daily for any erroneous blacklisting, but other than that literally dozens of emails are getting filtered a day. I can appreciate that.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-25 21:38

@kev Well, it's a fancy adblock plugin if you have one computer and that's it. The more stuff you have on your network, the more beneficial it becomes. So for me, an incomplete run down would look like this:

10 computers (ish)
9 tablets
2 phones
10 IoT devices
3 game systems
misc other connected devices

By setting up a single PiHole, I cover that entire range. That saves me a ton of time and effort over individual ad blocking.

@kelbot @joseph

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-25 20:41

@kev I should buckle down and get mine done just so I can talk about it with a little bit more understanding. I just updated my Internet service today, so now seems like the time to do it.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-24 15:57

@zonethesilver Depends on what you're looking for I guess. I'm using Mint 19 right now on my laptop, and RaspArch on my Pi workstation. I usually stick to Debian/Ubuntu flavors because it's what I'm used to. You'll get familiar structure if you stick to that (as a former Mint user). If you're looking to get into the weeds, Arch or Gentoo. Otherwise, vanilla Ubuntu for a Gnome distro, Kubuntu for KDE, Xubuntu for XFCE.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-24 15:39

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 20:43

@alex No, the Mastodon server doesn't handle the local notifications, and I can personally vouch for the fact that my notifications in Tusky are working fine. As long as your timelines are updating, then you should be receiving notifications unless there's something up with your local client or possibly an OS level configuration option. I don't spend a lot of time in iOS, so I can't be of much help there.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 18:09

@pinguino @codesections It's also something you have to keep practicing to stay good at. I used to be really good at 10 key because I was doing a lot of data entry that required it. These days my capabilities are average to below par because I just don't do it much anymore. I've noticed the same thing with programmer keys too. I'm much more proficient when I'm doing a lot of coding. I'm doing a lot more delegating these days than coding, and I notice the difference when I do break out an editor.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 18:00

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 16:47

@pinguino Yea, I think it's probably something that impacts "older" people more because there are a lot of people that had to learn it after their traditional education. When I started high school, there were a handful of Apple IIs in the whole place. They added a lot while I was there, but I still learned to type on a manual typewriter, not a computer keyboard. Even that was "optional". Others didn't take it at all.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 16:35

@alex Yea, I wish I could make a recommendation with something bordering on knowing something, but I can't. I've seen some iOS users using Tootdon, but I have never tried it myself and have no idea if it's any good.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 16:31

@pinguino Sometimes people who don't take any formal typing learn in funny ways. I know a guy who has been a system admin for a fair number of Linux systems for over 20 years now, and he literally types about 50WPM with 2 fingers. It's crazy to watch.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 15:59

Quick informal review of RaspArch.

Now that I've fixed the graphics issue, it's a nice system. It runs noticeably faster than my old workstation Pi running Raspbian, but that's not a fair comparison since Raspbian was running on a Pi 3B, and RaspArch is on a Pi 3B+.

This is my first foray into Arch systems, and it's bigger than I expected on the disk, but all in all pacman makes things pretty much as simple to use as apt-get.

All in all, slick little system. I like it so far.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 15:49

@DistroJunkie @ignitionigel That's a good question. RaspArch is basically what they're calling a "Remaster" of Linux Arch ARM, which is a rolling release. I haven't seen anywhere where anybody has specifically called RaspArch rolling, but I assume based on the fact that Linux Arch ARM is and RaspArch is basically that. I could be wrong.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 07:27

@mooshoe I did for a while, but I let both of them lapse.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-23 01:50

Finally got screen resolution working correctly. All I had to do was throw the entire screen resolution in as overscan. I might have to redo this whole thing because it barely fits on the SD card I'm using. For some reason, I expected Arch to be smaller.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-22 20:15

@flocke RaspArch is what they're calling a "remaster" of Arch Linux ARM. I don't know how much of it is different, but if you want to give this one a try, I'd love to know if you can figure out this display issue.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-19 22:18

@mooshoe And that's a very good question, and I think it's answer is subjective. Some people obviously think so, others not so much. I think all things being equal, I'd prefer to have control of my data than not. If Solid (or something like it) can offer similar options to what we find on the traditional web, I don't see a reason to NOT use it. If it can't, then I expect it will go nowhere.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-19 22:00

@mooshoe Well, I think there's a reason. When the web was originally created, it wasn't done so with individual security in mind, which is why companies like Google and Facebook can know so much about us. The idea behind Solid is a way to build in protection for your data. At least on a theoretically level, I can totally get behind that. Whether or not Solid is going to be worthwhile in and of itself, no clue. We'll probably have to wait and find out.

I THINK what they're trying to do is a private data repo that individuals (or maybe some kind of encrypted service?) manage that these web apps then access locally rather than store your data in the cloud? I could be completely wrong about all of that though. I was hoping someone could educate me.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-19 18:00

@isak@linuxrocks.online I'm not sure on how it works in the background, but Google recognizes spam numbers. There's two ways it can deal with them. One way, your phone rings and the screen lights up red instead of its normal blue to indicate a suspected spammer. I used this for a while, and I've never known it to be wrong, so I switched to method number two, where the phone automatically directs suspected spammers to voicemail. No more spam calls.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-19 17:28

Say what you will about Google, but their new spam call filtering is pretty awesome.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-18 18:14

This morning while I was talking to @0x4464@tiny.tilde.website and @codesections about Keybase, I had two separate issues come it at work regarding SSH keys. Now I've got encryption on the brain. It's like having a song stuck in your head, but with more hashes.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-18 18:13

Linux Fu: Scripting for Binary Files | Hackaday

https://hackaday.com/2018/06/29/linux-fu-scripting-for-binary-files/

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-18 18:11

At Rest Encryption | Linux Journal

https://www.linuxjournal.com/content/rest-encryption

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-18 16:59

@0x4464@tiny.tilde.website @codesections Well, by providing a hash instead of something human readable, it almost 100% removes the inclination to type in the validation manually. Without manual entry, a host of different issues disappear. Case checks, typos, omitted characters, etc. Any number of things that could cause a validation failure if not compensated for. By side stepping that issue, it makes for an easier experience for the end user and there are less variables to compensate for programmatically.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-18 16:40

@codesections @0x4464@tiny.tilde.website I think the hash is just much easier to find algorithmically, and you're basically using a unique key as a signature. That hash can only be used once. I'll admit that the benefits are pretty obscure, but when you're dealing with encryption, even the tiniest bit of added security is an improvement.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-18 15:58

@codesections @0x4464@tiny.tilde.website

Nothing. I think this requires some elaboration though.

Earlier you stated that identity verification was Keybase's key feature. I would disagree. Encrypted communication for everybody is Keybase's key feature.

There's a lot of information on this, and I think it's worth a read. I'd suggest their blog post found here:

https://keybase.io/blog/2015-07-15/keybase-raises-series-a

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-18 15:40

@codesections @0x4464@tiny.tilde.website A centralized location where you can verify the ownership of thousands of different accounts and pages without having to go digging all over the Internet?

Blort™ 🐀Ⓥ🥋☣️ @Blort 2018-07-06 17:03

#Blender gets all their videos blocked worldwide by #YouTube. #Armory3D has their #Patreon page closed down and their backers refunded without any notice as to why. All the #FOSS projects hosted by #GitHub now have their hosting at the mercy of #Microsoft.

And this is just a few of the recent examples.

When is the #FOSS community going to learn that we need to create and run our own infrastructure as well as apps?

Support #decentralised #FOSS infrastructure! (eg #PeerTube, #tilt, #Gitea etc)

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-15 22:57

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-15 22:22

@h4ck3r9 Yep. Never used to because my provider, Cox, has streaming services. Prior to the current administrations policies Net Neutrality it was considered illegal for providers to exempt their own streaming services from bandwidth limitations and not other services like Netflix, so bandwidth limitations weren't useful. The current admin dropped all that and my ISP turned on bandwidth caps almost immediately. Their services are exempt of course. Yay FCC.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-14 21:40

They have particular channels they watch over and over and over. If I could use an RSS reader to monitor those channels for new connect and automatically download them to my local Plex server, I'd save a lot of data per month, and my kids could still get their fix.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-13 03:57

@d4klutz I didn't try it on Windows either because..... well.... no Windows, but it was a little sketchy in Linux too. I tried using it over ssh from a Pi, but it didn't display correctly and in the end crashed my Mint 19 box I was running it on. I'm thinking I'll be avoiding it in the future. Neat gimmick though.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-13 03:56

@coffee Very cool. My only complaint about that is it syncs to some obscure location in your file system, but a simple link fixes that. All of the different file shares you create show up there. You can even drop stuff to it from the command line. If you sign up, look me up and I'd be happy to answer more questions. I don't work for them or anything, just like their product.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-13 03:32

@coffee Keybase is open source. It's got clients for Linux, macOS, Windows, Android, and even iOS. You can also do some tasks straight from a web browser. There's also plugins for Chrome and Firefox that add additional functionality such as adding a Keybase Chat button to verified account pages.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-13 03:30

@coffee Yep, you can create public, private, or team file spaces. Public files aren't encrypted, and they show up on your profile page on Keybase.io. Private files are encrypted and synced between devices. Further, you can create "joint" private shares, meaning if you and I were both using the system, I can create a file share that is kept in sync between our two computers allowing us to send files back and forth securely. I used this to send my wife tax information one year.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-13 01:54

@coffee It makes things easier. You can do anything you can do with Keybase without it, but it makes things super handy. Dropbox like file storage, end to end encrypted. A plugin for your browser so any verified accounts will show a Keybase chat right on their profile, allowing you to encrypt communications between you and someone you just met on Twitter without dealing with a key exchange or knowing any more about each other. I use it often, and I'm a fan. I'd be happy to answer more questions.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-12 22:11

Guido van Rossum Stepping Down from Role as Python's Benevolent Dictator For Life

https://www.linuxjournal.com/content/guido-van-rossum-stepping-down-role-pythons-benevolent-dictator-life

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-12 21:46

@timapple Yep, it was @mhall119. He's got such a service. You can find more details here:

https://gettogether.community

Mike Stone boosted
Liberapay @Liberapay 2018-07-12 21:23

Liberapay is in trouble, here's our blog post that explains the situation and what you should do if you're one of our 2000 active users: https://medium.com/liberapay-blog/liberapay-is-in-trouble-b58b40714d82

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-12 21:02

@fatboy Oh yea, that's EXACTLY what I meant to convey. 🙄

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-12 20:57

I tested out Browsh recently, and I'm still on the fence about it. It's a "text based" browser that is usable from the command line, but it kind of "cheats" to pull that off. In the background, it uses Firefox to render pages, and then passes off pre-rendered stuff to a web extension so you can view it in a terminal. It's NOT fast. It does display a text based site that is more faithful than you'll get from most terminal browsers. Not sure what I think at this point.

https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/07/browsh-modern-text-browser

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-12 18:49

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-07 19:48

@kev @ignitionigel For the record, we have no visibility into who is following who. It might be possible to see local follows if we delve into the DB, but we don't see it in any of the admin tools. Also, who people follow doesn't dictate what instances show up in the fed. I'm not sure how known instances get populated, but we currently have 1689 known instances (which isn't all of them). I'm pretty sure no one on our instance follows anybody from some of them.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-07 08:12

Mike Stone @mike 2018-07-04 03:30

@DistroJunkie That would be the point. :) I think there's a lot of negative backlash against "Clippy" because most people associate it with Microsoft's help system. I was working desktop support during the "Office 97" days, and Microsoft's help system was garbage, with or without Clippy, but because Clippy was "the face" of the help system, it has a lot of negative association. I look at Clippy as kind of a fun character that Microsoft used to try to cover failure.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-28 23:33

@brandon So, I put on all my winter gear, trudged through snow and cold to get to his office, and then waited for him to finish a meeting he was in. I then walked into his office, ejected the disk that was in his drive and hit the Enter key. The computer booted fine, and I put all my winter gear back on and trudged all the way back in the cold.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-28 23:31

@brandon I recall one when I was in college in Montana were a guy working for our housing group called us getting an error saying, "Invalid System Disk". This meant one of two things. Either your HD was toast, or there as a floppy in the disk drive. It was almost always the latter.

I told him to check the disk drive and eject a disk if it was there. He said there wasn't one. "Please double check." "No floppy".

*sigh*

It was a close to 1 mile walk and it was close to -20F (-29C) at the time.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-27 20:43

@fatboy No clue. I was waiting for a pizza, so I didn't get to in depth with the whole thing. I was just really shocked to see how much data it was using. I remember when I was in college getting complaints about my personal website because it had a 26k image on it. The whole site was less than 50k total, and people complained that it was just too big. Oh how times have changed.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-25 15:40

@BruteNerd I can't say that I've looked around much. I suppose it would depend on your interests. I've treated Mastodon kind of like email. Prior to coadmining Fosstodon with @kev, I pretty much picked an instance based on what I most enjoyed, but I didn't really need more than one. You CAN have more than one, but it doesn't add a lot of benefit in the long run. If you do want to add some more instances, I'd look at a Mastodon instance list and see what interests you.

https://instances.social/list

Maybe it's time to replace that aging Mac with something nice from System76?

"On The Sad State of Macintosh Hardware"

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-13 23:52

@mooshoe You mean why do I care that the meager protections that used to exist have just been erased? Why do I care that the companies that have made the Internet what it is has been given license to make it even worse? I would think that would be obvious.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-13 23:30

@mooshoe In my opinion, that's bad enough, but fast lanes, throttling, and site blocking also become perfectly legal. We haven't seen that yet, but I wouldn't be at all surprised. Basically, they're totally allowed to dismantle the Internet. I'm sure they'll never do that though. You know, unless they can make money doing it.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-13 23:17

@mooshoe It's like this. In boxing, punching below the belt is illegal. Does it still happen? Sure, occasionally. What you're saying is it won't be any different if punching below the belt is suddenly allowed.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-13 23:00

@mooshoe Actually, they haven't. That type of behavior is called "Zero Rating", and previously it was widely frowned upon by the FCC. After Ajit Pai started, he killed any and all investigations into the practice, and then killed Net Neutrality over the protests of the majority of the American people. Zero rating is now open season on consumers, and I'm guessing it will only happen more and more often.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-13 22:43

@mooshoe Not beneficial in my case because even encrypted data still counts as data. All the VPN would do is keep the ISP from knowing that I'm streaming Netflix, but since they're just charging by the MB unless it's from their service, they're pulling money out of my pocket with or without one.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-13 22:28

@mooshoe Some things have already changed. Speaking anecdotally, after the initial announcement that Net Neutrality was being killed, my ISP implemented bandwidth caps, which makes streaming without paying for a premium plan difficult. They granted an exception for their own streaming services, so if I purchase and stream content from them I don't have to worry about exceeding my data allotment. You can certainly expect to see a lot more of that kind of behavior.

Mike Stone boosted

Mike Stone boosted
Steve has ☕️ for brains @sivy 2018-06-12 22:51

So we have Mastodon, pleroma, gnusocial in the messaging space of the fediverse, pixelfed playing in the instaphoto space, and peertube making progress in video. What other non-text AP services are popping up? I want to support as many as I can - with encouragement if not ca$h

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-11 21:11

@ignitionigel @codesections @pla1

I should also mention just for the record, I don't work for them and I'm not affiliated with them in any way. I just like their stuff. :)

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-11 21:08

@ignitionigel @codesections @pla1

I forgot to mention that Keybase announced in March that they were being funded by Stellar (a group that has a bitcoin type currency). Keybase is planning on adding a currency exchange feature in the future, so you'll be able to exchange crypto-currency securely and anonymously with someone on the Internet just by knowing their Twitter handle (it would be REALLY nice to see Mastodon in here too). That's a pretty cool option.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-11 21:01

@ignitionigel @codesections @pla1

Also, Keybase's business model is similar to companies like Red Hat. They provide all of their tools to the end user free of charge, but they have consulting services and support models for enterprise. They've also done moderately well with VCs, so I believe they're doing OK for themselves.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-06-11 20:59

@ignitionigel Well, originally Keybase was designed to be a way to facilitate encrypted communications by serving as a key exchange. You could get someones public key information just by knowing their Twitter handle for example. Keybase also focuses on making encryption easier for anybody, even the less tech savvy. They've been adding tools over time, and some are less for the "unsavvy" than others, but they've continued with the original goal of encouraging encryption.

@codesections @pla1

I COULD have left it up there and figured out a less demanding way of getting it, but that would have required a lot more time.

The car did really well. I taxed the cruise control and the stereo quite a lot and it performed admirably.

Mike Stone boosted
halcy​:icosahedron: @halcy 2018-06-05 23:19

Hey! Mastodon.py 1.3.0 is finally out, with lots of stuff in it! Highlights include:

* Streaming should break a lot less now, and there's better error handling
* All endpoints from Mastodon v2.3.0 and v2.4.0 and one from v2.1.0: media_update, webpush support (including some utilities for the cryptography), account fields, pinned statuses
* More tests, more documentation, etc

Thanks to everyone who helped!

GitHub: https://github.com/halcy/Mastodon.py/releases/tag/1.3.0

Docs: https://mastodonpy.readthedocs.io/en/1.3.0/

#mastodonpy #python 🐍

Mike Stone boosted
SeaSharp @seasharp 2018-06-05 20:27

Followed this very well-written blog post detailing the process of self-hosting a git repo...

https://www.kennwilson.com/notes/2013/08/self-hosted-remote-git-repositories/

Ended up with a snappy little git endpoint fenced in with git-shell and enough self-hosting capability to be happy without a repo web FE.

Hope this helps someone else digging into the same!

#github #selfhosting #git

Lord Guysbert de Fieri :lithroace_flag: @InspectorCaracal 2018-06-05 16:54

PSA: don't forget, your instance moderators need you to help by reporting anything that you think might violate the rules!

Reporting something doesn't automatically penalize anyone, so *you* don't need to worry about whether something is really actionable.

That's *our* job as moderators! All *you* need to do is help make sure we don't miss things by reporting them.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-28 19:04

@gc
The Multifed? The capability to have a fediverse isolated from the general fediverse solves that problem. Strong protections on a user and instance level mean we can block compromised users and instances from invading a particular fediverse in the Multifed.

(I now dedicate myself to making "Multifed" a real word people use)

Mike Stone boosted
greg 🌲🌲 @gc 2018-05-28 18:27

I dread the day that silicon valley 'discovers' the fediverse and it starts getting popular in a Big way.

the day that happens is the day that VC money starts pouring into startups that will try to 'develop' (ie systematically colonize, commercialize, and exploit) the fediverse, which is, as of today, one of the few non-capitalist (as in non-commercialized) spaces left on the internet.

how do we prevent this from happening? how do we make it impossible for this to happen in the first place?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-11 23:58

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-11 18:04

@timapple I haven't read a lot of comics, but I've used Calibre for eBooks and for a while I had a Calibre server running on a Pi (I repurposed it and haven't rebuilt it since). Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-11 16:04

@brandon Quite often with AI and Deep Learning, how thedecisions are made is a black box regardless of whether the source is open or not. It's been a matter of discussion on whether AI should be required to show it's work. As with most things regarding AI, it's still up in the air and it's debatable whether any decision would be enforceable anyway. Even with an free AI and an open data set, it could still be a mystery how conclusions are reached by the AI.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-11 16:00

@DistroJunkie it's something that is possible with a general AI if care isn't made to imbue that AI with certain rules. The issue then becomes, if one general AI can be developed, more than one general AI can be developed. How do you make sure that the required rules are applied to any and all AIs created? Should it be a government body? Should it be a regulatory commission outside of government? Should it be mutually assured destruction? I don't think anybody has a good answer yet.

@brandon

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-11 15:59

@DistroJunkie I think the concern that many people have is that if a general AI is developed, it makes decisions on its own. There may come a time when that AI's motivations may conflict with humanity in general. For example, if a general AI is tasked with protecting the environment, and it determines that the biggest negative impact on the environment comes from humanity, so it decides it needs to remove humanity from the system to save the environment. Not the original intent, but..

@brandon

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-11 15:44

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-10 23:39

The only solution I can see is giving AI to the public through open source. It's one of the reasons I'm so rabid in my support of Mycroft.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-10 18:00

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-10 17:28

@DelusionalAI It only looks off balance because it IS off balance. It's oriented for right handed people, so the controls operate on the right hand side of the phone. If you're holding the phone with the left, those controls become slightly awkward. I don't mind the right-hand leaning interface (for right-handed people), but a centralized UI or a configurable option would be nice.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 23:56

@timapple Another thing I found interesting was this. I listened to Keith and Noah's interview, but they didn't cover this. During an interview, Kan Liu (Chrome OS director of product management) said, "Just go to wherever you normally get those apps, whether it’s on the websites or through apt-get in the Linux terminal, and seamlessly get those apps like any other Linux distribution." That makes it sound like (at least to me) that command line won't be the only install option.

@fatboy

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 23:10

@timapple I'm not sure. I'd normally agree, but the one thing that gives me pause is how large of a share ChromeOS devices have in the education market. There are LOTS of ChromeOS computers in schools, and that's a great place for students to be introduced to new things. It will probably see marginal uptake outside of education if it doesn't get an easier installation process, but I think if Google sees some adoption, they'll take care of that.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 22:24

I want some opinions on Google's new Duplex technology. I realize that Google isn't a favorite of many people, but I'd like opinions that are not about Google as a company itself, but more about the underlying tech.

1. What do you think of the tech in general?

2. Do you find the fact that it appears to closely mimic normal speech disconcerting?

3. Would you speak differently to a caller if you knew it was a digital assistant even if you couldn't tell the difference without notification?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 21:49

@jondavidenas Yep, I have a Mark I that I use, and I've ordered a Mark II. Is there anything specific you'd like to know?

@dpreacher@mastodon.rocks

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 21:40

@Anna One I'd suggest is Mycroft. It's an open source AI project that installs onto a Linux box or a Raspberry Pi, and new users can write their own skills for it using Python. They can add to pre-existing skills or write their own new ones. It can be as easy or complex as they'd like to make it.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 20:54

@kev I hadn't noticed. I don't see anything in the news.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 19:38

@kev Now I feel like I have to logoff so I can see it.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 19:37

@kev Also cool. You've been busy.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 19:37

@kev Very nice.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 19:34

@hinterwaeldler The Linux apps do run in a VM, but it's transparent to the end user. Basically, Linux apps can be run by clicking an icon just like any other app on any other OS. They run like any other ChromeOS/Android app would run on the platform, and there's no visual difference between them. Performance will obviously vary with hardware, but the word is that the VM starts quickly and apps are responsive. They can be installed with standard Debian apt-get commands or a software store.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 19:28

@fatboy Me too, and there's a nice precedent here. It gives people an opportunity to buy an easy to use and inexpensive computer that will do most of the tasks that a typical computer user would do. We're not talking about high end graphics artists or sound engineers, just typical users. If they need/want more beyond what ChromeOS offers, they can now download and use apps from the Linux ecosystem. If they want more than ChromeOS, Linux becomes a very tempting choice due to app familiarity.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-09 18:55

https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/05/google-confirms-linux-apps-support-chromebooks

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-07 23:03

@bob It would be a start, but it wouldn't address patching. No company intentionally puts vulnerabilities into their products (unless the NSA asks them to), but they're there. Right now it feels like the support window of "smart appliances" is less time than it takes for you to get it home. Any inadvertent "features" in the code are going to be there for a long, long time.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-07 22:46

@bob If we're lucky it will be that short. Unfortunately we're at a place where we want to have "smart" functionality in our appliances but our technology is advancing much more quickly than appliance "technology". It leaves this gap of unsupported (and frankly dangerous) equipment. At this juncture, I just don't see a good solution currently available. Hopefully someone will come up with something workable here soon.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-07 22:38

@bob I agree, but it begs the question: Is a 3 year update promise better than the virtually nonexistent one that currently exists for most "smart appliances"?

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-07 22:23

@Dekkard Yea, 300 wouldn't be overly unusual, but 500 would probably would make into the "horrible" range.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-07 19:32

@brandon Sure thing! Oh, and while you're at it, can you please fix the indent in the apply function? It's been driving me nuts for days! :D

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-07 19:30

@brandon Yep, it just changes all upper case characters to lower case characters. Any and all combinations.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-07 19:26

@brandon Looking better and better. If you did a INPUT_VAR=`echo $1|tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]'` instead of using the $1 variable in your case statement, you'd save yourself a lot of time and effort on error checking.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-05-06 18:37

@tatpap@mastodon.rocks @kev I think it's worth pointing out that Apple's "privacy focus" is a relatively new thing for them, and up until 2016 they WERE an advertising company. They just failed at it miserably. They tried to compete with Google on Google's home turf, and Google squished them like a bug. Apple has only become focused on its users privacy since they shuttered their own ad network and Google continued to eat their lunch. They have few other competition vectors left.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAd

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-30 21:09

@Matter I don't know that it's that he doesn't want to stop using proprietary software, just that he wants to continue using the services that he's been using. Unfortunately many of these services we all use are not just closed source in their applications, but they're proprietary in their protocols, making it nearly impossible for 3rd party FOSS developers to create an open alternative. If he wasn't so tied to those services, I'm sure things would have gone better for him.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-29 18:38

@brandon Fair enough, but wget doesn't have the capability of creating a list like that (at least that I'm aware of). You're going to have to download the site recursively and then parse the individual html files if you want to get links outside of that particular file hierarchy. That's going to be a lot more overhead and time.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-29 17:43

@brandon You can also use lynx, like:

lynx -dump -listonly https://www.website.com

That will generate a list for you. Probably easier than wget even.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-29 17:28

@brandon Not as hard as you'd think. You can wget -r and just built a list of URLs to post based on html files and directories.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-29 17:25

@seasharp@crowsnest.libre.audio @seasharp@linuxrocks.online @brandon Probably don't need to get that complex about it. Since archive.is already archives the site, you should just need to have a CLI method of submitting a URL. It's basically just a http post.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-29 17:11

@brandon @therealmatthartley @seasharp@linuxrocks.online @seasharp@crowsnest.libre.audio I don't know of any. I know it uses the Memento API. There might be an opportunity there.

@dpreacher@mastodon.rocks It's just an internal code name for the next major update to Windows 10. I believe it's due around October, but I could be wrong. It probably is wise to test for it unless your development cycle is pretty short.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-24 20:56

Mike Stone @mike 2018-04-17 15:58

@33Nicolas Sure. Sorry about the paywall. It didn't show up on my phone for some reason.

MIcrosoft announced Azure Sphere, which is their end-to-end solution for connected microcontroller powered devices. It's a "Microsoft Operating System", but the real interesting bit is this: It's based on a customized Linux kernel.

So, the real takeaway of the announcement is, Microsoft has just released it's own version of Linux.

Not bad for a "cancer" eh?

https://hackaday.com/2018/03/06/the-sensor-array-that-grew-into-a-robot-cat/

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-29 16:43

@mqqr4M5pB7ghewdWZfgq Welcome aboard.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-29 04:32

@mhall119 I'm with @DistroJunkie on that one. Our instance rocks. As for how you move it, you can go to the gear icon in the upper left near your avatar. There's an option to export who you follow to a CSV file. That's where the import is too. You can also request an archive of all your posts. Unfortunately, there's no MOVE between instances. You just create a new account on the new instance and import your following list. You can't import your toots, and people will need to refollow you.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-28 20:13

@Angle I think you're probably thinking of the Alpheidae. They're actually a shrimp, but the rest of that blends.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-28 15:05

@0x3F Absolutely, which will make it even more important for the FOSS community to work together and live up to their ideals. If every project tries to do their own thing, even those rare and small data sets will be unusable by other groups, which will hamstring everybody. Then it will be impossible to complete with proprietary offerings.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-27 23:59

"Whoever wins AI will own the future" says Andrew Ng, Stanford professor and original DeepMind team member.

I agree with this in principle, but requiring ethical rules for AI is complicated. The only way that's enforceable is if a select few accountable parties control AI, and that in and of itself is bad in my opinion.

How do you enforce ethical rules for AI when AI is open source and anybody can create artificial intelligence in their own home?

Article not required:

http://www.cityam.com/282994/ai-needs-ethical-rules-gain-acceptance

Mike Stone boosted
Jean Snyman @stringlytyped 2018-03-25 14:47

While there isn't an official way to link your Mastodon account with Keybase, you can prove your identity manually by signing a message with the Keybase CLI. Then, anyone that meets you via the fediverse can communicate with you securely by verifying your signature. There is a good explanation of how to do this at https://ryanmaynard.co/mastodon-keybase

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-10 04:38

@brandon It can't do that yet, but the ground work is there for it. I'm really hoping they can meet the expectations they're setting.

Of course, because the whole thing is open source, if you a Mycroft device and an on prem back-end system, we can always do it ourselves. One of the best things about open source. Even if the company goes belly-up your'e still covered.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-10 04:35

@brandon Yea, the customizability of the Mycroft system is by far it's biggest asset. That alone gives it a real shot in an enterprise environment. Seriously, imagine this:

User1: "Hey Mycroft, restart the dev CMS server."
Mycroft to Admin: "User1 would like to restart the dev CMS server. Is that OK?"
Admin: "Yes"
Mycroft to User1: "A restart of the dev CMS instance was authorized by Admin. Instance restarted."

I would pay a fair amount of my companies money for that ability.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-10 04:27

@brandon Naw, Persona is the feature set that allows you to customize the answers that Mycroft returns. This way you can add things like, "What is the IP address for ProdServer01?" or "What is my wife's favorite color?". With Persona and a back-end server, your Mycroft can be completely customized. You can even change the name to anything you want, so it doesn't have to stay Mycroft. It's your own personal Jarvis.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-10 04:24

@brandon Combine that with the features they're talking about with Persona, and it's going to be a really sweet setup. Has some real potential with in the Enterprise too. I'm really looking forward to seeing what they release with the Mark II. Could be amazing.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-10 04:21

@brandon They've got some cool stuff coming, including the ability to run all the back-end processes off a system in your house. It requires more oomph than you're going to get from a Raspberry Pi, but with a sufficiently powerful home system, you can literally run the whole thing on prem. Funnel all your requests through a onion router and VPN and it doesn't get much more secure than that. Your own personalized assistant that doesn't tell the ad networks what you're talking about.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-10 04:17

@brandon Not yet, but it's on the list for features they're planning on adding. They're also planning on adding two way communication between two units, so you can use them for an intercom in your house.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-03-10 04:05

@brandon Well, I already ordered one myself. It would be great for it to have a friend though. :)

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-20 19:52

@DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks @RyuKurisu I don't know really. Based on the information that they say they're going to be collecting, a fingerprint of your system could be made. Changes could be tracked, and that fingerprint could be used to identify your system later. I'm sure it's paranoia, but even if Canonical isn't planning on using that information, it's there if their systems get cracked. I'm sure I give away more information daily without knowing it, but there are some places I just don't expect it.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-19 22:41

@dpreacher@mastodon.rocks
This is one of the reasons I support Mycroft so much. I like the idea of the assistant, but hate the privacy loss. Ideally I'd have an assistant that could keep track of all my personal details, like updating my calendar and maybe even answering some of my email, but would be entirely hosted in my home, secured and encrypted. Mycroft is the closest to that. They plan on having on prem hosting and all of your requests even through their service is anonymized.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-16 21:52

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-16 21:51

@RyuKurisu @DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks I still have questions. Like, if I upgrade my 17.10 to 18.04 instead of installing from scratch, is it going to be on or off? I'd definitely prefer an opt-in instead of an opt-out for cases where someone may just be in a hurry and forget to uncheck or something like that. Opt-out allows for too many "accidental" agreements. Opt-In means you're volunteering, and you have to manually do that. Not just be in a hurry and not notice a checked box.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-16 21:49

@brian @kev I started out using an editor called eve, and then went to emacs when I started using Unix/Linux on a regular basis. emacs was just too clunky, so I switched to nano for a while, but it wasn't long until I discovered just how powerful vi(m) can be, and I've never looked back.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-07 17:17

@welshgeekboy I'm not sure about the Ubuntu. It's an abandoned project that Canonical is no longer supporting, so you'd need to have a phone it's supportedon, and it was never a finished product, so it may not function for you at all. Unfortunately phones are an area where it's difficult to find a good PRIVATE option unless you go back to a flip phone. Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-06 22:26

@DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks There are things like the laptop form factor will always be superior for, even if you've got a smaller version in your pocket. I can't think of anybody off the top of my head that would prefer to create spread sheets on a phone vs a computer even though they technically can. I'm also torn about Google dominating the PC OS space. I'd prefer it was someone with less interest in spying on me, but that isn't Microsoft. Given a choice between Microsoft or Google, I'd go Google.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-06 21:41

@DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks Apple couldn't have dominated the market for the simple reason that they kept their OS and their hardware proprietary. ONLY Apple could make a macOS device, and Apple wanted to charge a premium for their products. Google isn't making the same mistake with ChromeOS. Quite the contrary, with their cloud based model, they've made it so someone can easily jump between devices with no loss of data. This is a perfect setup for schools or multi-user, non-technical homes.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-06 21:12

@DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks Well, I think quite a lot of the ChromeOS devices out there exist in the education market, which is a big deal because it's where kids are learning to use computers. Those kids grow up to buy computers, and there's a good chance that they're going to buy what's familiar to them. If they're familiar with a ChromeOS device, you could begin to see more and more of those devices outside of the education market.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-02-02 03:42

@dpreacher@mastodon.rocks Heh, well, I have to read to figure out how to do some of this stuff.

I'm writing a script to monitor our FTP server at work. Really, I just want to connect, download a file, verify its contents, and upload a different file.

I've got pysftp installed, and I'm working on the authentication. At first I was going to hard code a password encoded base64, but now I'm just going to use the ssh private key. Easier and more secure. Still, there are some things I haven't figured out yet.

Mike Stone @mike 2018-01-11 21:28

Don't you just love when you run into old code and you have no idea what the heck you were doing?

#!/bin/ksh

if [ ! -f file.txt ]
then
echo 1 > file.txt
else
INC_VAR='head -1 file.txt`
cat file.txt;echo 2 > file.txt
fi

That's the whole script. What the heck is that good for??

SMH

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-14 15:49

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-06 01:23

@bashroot I am not an ISP, and government intervention (in this case) is explicitly designed to limit the capability of corporations to limit my access to a free and neutral Internet. It in no way impedes a corporations capability to compete in a fair marketplace.

Mike Stone boosted
EFF @EFF 2017-12-05 23:52

Tonight: @internetarchive hosts a panel on #NetNeutrality, with speakers including Evan Engstrom of @EngineOrg and… https://twitter.com/i/web/status/938194283768582144 source: https://twitter.com/eff/status/938194283768582144

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 23:28

The future without Net Neutrality.

http://www.zdnet.com/article/trumps-fcc-gets-ready-to-take-a-chainsaw-to-net-neutrality/

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 22:55

@bashroot I couldn't disagree with you more. Snowden and Vault7 had literally NOTHING to do with Net Neutrality regulation. Snowden happened in 2013, and Net Neutrality wasn't even passed until 2015. Net Neutrality has no provisions for monitoring. None.

Monopolies absolutely could exist without government, and without oversight of some kind corporations would be free to stomp on individual rights all they want. And they have. They will continue to do so if they think they'll make a dime more.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 22:31

@kev
I'm looking for something too. I'm using Thunderbird right now, and I'm not a fan so far. I don't want to use Evolution, but I haven't had a desktop email client for so long I have no idea what's good in that market.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 22:23

@bashroot
Net Neutrality is not a government program. The government doesn't monitor the Internet, and doesn't record information. It's simply a series of rules that can be used for enforcement if a corporation violates neutrality. I'm not sure how the government could possibly "abuse" the power to enforce neutrality.

Net Neutrality rules don't apply to "The Internet". They keep corporations from impeding a free market. They're very similar to monopoly laws in that way.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 21:45

@bashroot Not true. There were several instances of throttling and other violations, but there were no regulations to enforce. Even if it were true, there was no need for speed limits before there were cars either.

I am not against regulations of it ensures equality, which is what the Net Neutrality regulations do. I'm also not against monopoly laws which prevent companies like Microsoft from locking down boot and requiring Windows. Regulations aren't inherently bad.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 20:46

@dpreacher@mastodon.rocks
I wish. Unfortunately the work laptop is Windows, and it fell down and went boom.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 20:24

Work laptop full down today. Won't even boot. I'm trying to get most of my work done on a tablet.

It's working. Kinda.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-05 15:56

@bashroot
Pretty sure we don't. Those rules are all that keeps corporate interests from walking all over the end user. Without them, corporations are free to charge extra for types of bandwidth, throttle, and even block competing services. Unless you want your ISP deciding what parts of the Internet you can see, you're not on Pai's side.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-04 23:50

As expected. The FCC as it currently exists doesn't care what the populace wants.

https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/12/fcc-chair-refuses-to-delay-net-neutrality-vote-despite-pending-court-case/

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-04 23:16

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-04 22:53

Mike Stone @mike 2017-12-04 22:48

I don't know a lot about our VPN setup, but I know every time I try to connect it whines that I don't have an "approved antivirus" installed (which is basically McAfee). Can't seem to get around that so far. It just dumps me to this limbo version of our network and I have access to a pretty sparse list of things. Nothing that I need that I don't have access to already.

@33Nicolas I'm not one that does audio or video, but @therealmatthartley does, and hopefully he'll correct me if I'm incorrect in this.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-11-07 20:18

Question for people worried about "SkyNet". Isn't it worse for us to NOT study AI?

If AI isn't open and in the hands of the people, it WILL be studied by corporations and governments, either overtly or covertly. If the people don't have AI equal to or better than the corporations and governments, AI will be used against us. In my opinion, that's what we REALLY have to worry about when it comes to AI.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-19 16:56

@33Nicolas I'm all for a voluntary donation system. I've seen many content creators using Patreon, and I contribute to some. I wouldn't mind "subscribing" to an authors content, and if you can get a couple thousand people to contribute one dollar a month, you can make a decent living.

I'm not a fan of these sites adding a miner and leaving up ads. Instead of using it as an alternate, they're using it as additional revenue. I also see no promises these funds are going to authors.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-19 16:50

@33Nicolas Ad blocking software keeps many content creators from getting the compensation they deserve for their work. The flip of that is ads have become so much of an imposition users are looking for any way to return their browsing experience to some semblance of normal.

Maybe this is middle ground? A way for creators to be compensated without annoying the heck out of the people reading? Still, I think there needs to be some sort of disclosure before hand.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-19 16:46

@33Nicolas I don't actually mind the approach in principle. I despise the ad based approach that many sites have gone to. In my opinion, it's become visual spam. I see the issue from the perspective of the people producing the content as well. I occasionally mash the keyboard like an intoxicated gorilla, but I don't expect anybody to pay me. For people who make a living writing because they have actual skills, it's got to be extremely frustrating to not be compensated for that work.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-16 17:54

@warrax I didn't take it personally.

The comprehensive SOPs are relatively new for us. We had several years where we had people in and out and no SOPs. We had exactly the problems you're talking about. My current group has been great though. They've all been around a number of years now and they've built up a great support system. It's let me focus a lot more on my "development" stuff. It might not sound like it, but I'm really happy about where they are right now. They're doing a great job.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-16 17:35

@warrax Ha! It could be!

I love my team, but they're a Tier 1 group, so they have a collection of SOPs they adhere to, but any issues that occur outside of those SOPs are handled by me. If I happen to be on vacation (especially vacations longer than a day or two), sometimes issues outside of the SOPs are "guessed at" or they're handled by other people who don't always understand the processes. Either can cause bad things. So far, looks like things went smoothly while I was gone!

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-16 17:14

I've been back to work for 2 hours and 15 minutes after a vacation of more than a week. So far, no calamity. Could it be my team has accomplished the impossible?

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-16 01:22

@ignitionigel @kev @33Nicolas Motorola had a lot of good ideas with Atrix, but they also did some stupid stuff. First, the dock was proprietary. If you want this kind of thing to succeed, you need someone like Google to build it into the OS and open it up for any OEM to use it with a standardized connection (USB-C anybody?). 2nd, the interface they used was OK, but I'm not sure it was specifically Linux. It was called WebTop. Fuzzy on details.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-15 18:36

Mike Stone @mike 2017-10-01 02:01

@dpreacher@mastodon.rocks Ha!! Not far from the truth!

Window of time. We're supposed to get the file in question sometime between midnight and 2:00am. It didn't show, so our automated process kicked off an alert that called me to figure out what the heck was going on.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-29 22:45

Thanks Gary.

http://www.androidauthority.com/what-is-a-blockchain-gary-explains-801514/

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-29 22:18

@kev is using Piwik instead of Google Analytics. This is how it went.

https://kevq.uk/de-googling-my-life-02-analytics/

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-29 06:38

@clif Is it giving you an error of any kind, or just not working? Also, are you using a mobile client or just the web interface?

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-28 21:06

@DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks That's why we automate so much stuff. Automated processes watch the servers, and errors are reported through a system called MIR3. It handles the calls at pretty much any hour.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-28 20:02

@DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks Thankfully that sort of thing never really happens to me. We're more of a "real time" department. If something sat that long unaddressed, heads would roll. I get more of the stuff like, "Company A hasn't updated their data in 15 minutes. Find out what's wrong ASAP!!"

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-28 20:01

@Toby_Cowles @Toby_Cowles@mastodon.rocks Hi.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-28 17:52

@warrax Originally a lot of the Twitter communication was done via SMS, so the limitation was put in place to conform to SMS length limitations. That's ancient history now, but they've just stuck with the tradition up until now. Why they're doing it now is beyond me. I like Mastodon's 500. Works for me.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-28 17:49

@dpreacher@mastodon.rocks Some of them are support calls from other time zones, but most of it is automated. We have an extensive set of custom monitors that watch all sorts of things, from which processes are running to whether we receive files from customers inside of specific windows. That's what happened last night. We didn't receive a file from a customer when it was expected.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-28 17:46

@warrax That's what they keep saying!

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-14 00:14

@kev @BNolet@mastodon.rocks @DistroJunkie@mastodon.rocks There are a number of things I would like to see. Two-factor where you combine biometrics with traditional passcodes is a great start. I would also like to see "distress" options. Example, I use my ring fingerprint and 654321 as a passcode and it lets me in fine. If I use my pointer fingerprint and 321654 as the passcode, my phone is immediately securely wiped and distress notifications are sent to defined contacts/services (including possibly the police).

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-13 18:54

I don't necessarily trust this, but my question becomes, why remove the fingerprint? Why not leave the fingerprint and allow a face/fingerprint combination for two-factor authorization? I don't know why this isn't an option anyway. I'd feel more secure about my phone's security if I could use a fingerprint and a code, or even a fingerprint and my face.

https://www.newscientist.com/article/2147204-why-the-iphone-xs-face-id-is-a-terrible-way-to-secure-your-data/

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-13 17:45

@BNolet@mastodon.rocks Noticed.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-12 20:27

We're moving buildings at work in October, and next week we're going over to the new building to test the network. I'm doing some baseline testing of our existing network, and "pathetic" is being overly generous. Right now, we're pulling down about 300KB a second. That's it.

Keep in mind, this is a rental property and the network isn't managed by us. It will be ours in the new building. I'm REALLY looking forward to the move.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-05 17:33

@BNolet@mastodon.rocks I agree there are things that Google could do better, but it's difficult to find a non-Linux company that has done more for Linux. There are obviously companies like Redhat and Canonical that put a lot of time and effort into Linux, but for them Linux is the product. That's not what Google does. Even when it comes to their operating systems, the OS isn't Google's product. It's a means to getting to it's actual product.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-05 17:27

@BNolet@mastodon.rocks That actually highlights one of Linux's strengths. True, any company of any size can take Linux and use it to get their products off the ground. Even if they move to something else eventually, changes that they made are still made public and available to everybody. That's head and shoulders above BSD licenses that let companies like Apple take their code and keep changes secret, and we don't even have to mention closed source licenses. Bleh.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-05 16:05

@BNolet@mastodon.rocks I think it's a good question academically, but I'm not sure it matters in the long run. Seeing that number going up improves Linux's mindshare (at least I think it does), and that's a big step towards further adoption of Linux in general.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-04 08:49

@miwilc@mastodon.rocks For me it's helped to break things down to the binary representation. Example:

rw- would be 110 because the r and w flags are flipped, but the x is not.

This is helpful to me at least because 110 is 6 in binary. If you wanted rwx, that would be 111, which is 7 in binary.

This makes it quick and easy to figure out your permissions.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-09-03 15:19

@lx Unfortunately it's a self-fulfilling situation. Why would anybody spend the time and effort to write a decent client for Mastodon if no one is using it?

Mike Stone @mike 2017-08-20 08:23

@kev You know, I do think it's probably a touch overwhelming for new users having all these distros, but adding 2 or 3 or 10 more isn't going to make things significantly worse. Having options that are significantly better (if that's the case) would improve things. In my opinion, there's no real downside to adding a few more.

Mike Stone @mike 2017-08-06 18:07

BNoletmastodon.rocks A couple reasons.

One, the admin for fosstodon, @kev is a friend from years ago. He was even patient enough with me that he used to let me write for his site before he sold it to ride motorcycles around the UK.

Two, he's trying to build a specifically around FOSS, which I think is a good idea. Even without the Fed, it would make for great discourse.

Three, Mastodon's strength in being distributed is also a weakness. If one of these hosts goes away, we're boned.
